channel.title: NYT > U.S. News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2020 The New York Times Company

item.title: Coronavirus Live Updates: U.S. News on Pandemic
item.description: Democrats in Pennsylvania’s House of Representatives accused Republicans of keeping a lawmaker’s positive coronavirus test a secret. Even the hardest-hit cities are far from herd immunity.
item.media:description: Food distribution in Jackson Heights, Queens, this week.

item.title: Indian Casinos Defy California's Reopening Plans
item.description: Some casinos swung open their doors last week despite health concerns. “This virus does not recognize jurisdictional boundaries,” Gov. Gavin Newsom wrote to tribal leaders.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Fuller
item.media:description: People waited outside of the Viejas Casino and Resort in Alpine, Calif., last week.

item.title: Live Updates: George Floyd Protests in Minneapolis Turn Violent
item.description: Stores were set alight and officers fired tear gas and rubber bullets as a wave of protests erupted across South Minneapolis.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters lit fires and burned buildings in Minneapolis overnight Wednesday.

item.title: An ‘Avalanche of Evictions’ Could Be Bearing Down on America’s Renters
item.description: The economic downturn is shaping up to be particularly devastating for renters, who are more likely to be lower-income and work hourly jobs cut during the pandemic.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Mervosh
item.media:credit: Maddie McGarvey for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sandy Naffah in her apartment in Euclid, Ohio, with her dog, Shadow. Ms. Naffah is worried about eviction after losing two part-time jobs during the coronavirus pandemic.

item.title: Management of Bailout Money Poses Political Test for Trump
item.description: Democrats are mobilizing to turn an economic bailout into a liability for President Trump even as some Republicans seek to embrace it.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport and Nick Corasaniti
item.category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)
item.media:description: The Trump administration has faced criticism for its implementation of a small business lending program, an issue Democrats are seizing on in the 2020 campaign.

item.title: Defying Trump, Twitter Doubles Down on Labeling Tweets
item.description: Twitter continued fact-checking posts even as President Trump threatened to limit protections for social media companies.
item.dc:creator: Kate Conger and Mike Isaac
item.media:description: Twitter headquarters in San Francisco.

item.title: The National Anthem’s Path to Fame Began With Little Fanfare
item.description: The song that became “The Star-Spangled Banner” had a modest debut in a newspaper. That first dated printing will be auctioned online at Christie’s.
item.dc:creator: James Barron

item.title: North Koreans Accused of Laundering $2.5 Billion for Nuclear Program
item.description: The Justice Department unsealed an indictment accusing nearly three dozen people of using shell companies to launder billions through the global financial system.
item.dc:creator: Katie Benner
item.media:credit: Kim Won Jin/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The North Korean leader Kim Jong Un has recently returned to public view after a weekslong absence.

item.title: Soldier Stopped Shooting on Bridge by Driving Into Gunman, Kansas Police Say
item.description: The soldier, who is assigned to Fort Leavenworth, drove his car into a man who was firing “randomly” at drivers on a bridge between Kansas and Missouri, the police said.
item.dc:creator: Christine Hauser
item.media:credit: John Richmeier/Leavenworth Times, via Associated Press
item.media:description: The authorities gathering on Centennial Bridge after a shooting near Leavenworth, Kan.

item.title: House Pulls Surveillance Measure After Trump Tells Republicans to Vote No
item.description: A bipartisan compromise to reinstate expired F.B.I. powers to investigate terrorism and espionage collapsed amid bipartisan opposition.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Fandos and Charlie Savage
item.media:description: Speaker Nancy Pelosi said the House would instead negotiate with the Senate to bridge their differences.

item.title: Pompeo Hits Out at China
item.description: A threat over Hong Kong, and controversy in the education world: This is your morning tip sheet.
item.dc:creator: Giovanni Russonello

item.title: Can You Get the Virus From a Surface?
item.description: And what else you need to know today.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times

item.title: Returning, and Awakening, to the Beauty of Rural Alabama
item.description: Having traveled to Alabama to wait out the coronavirus pandemic, a photographer reassesses his relationship with his childhood and his hometown.
item.dc:creator: Scott Baker

item.title: Couple Bilked Medicaid for $13 Million to Pay for Lavish Lifestyle, U.S. Says
item.description: Latisha and Timothy Harron spent the money on a private jet, shopping sprees at Tiffany, wine and clothes that they flaunted on social media, prosecutors said.
item.dc:creator: Neil Vigdor

item.title: Camping in the West? Like Everything These Days, It’s Complicated
item.description: “Every state is different. In some states, every municipality is different.”
item.dc:creator: Steve Knopper
item.media:credit: Benjamin Rasmussen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Let’s get camping: Earlier this month, Douglas Hollabaugh set up a tent in Golden Gate Canyon State Park, outside of Golden, Colo.

item.title: U.S. to Expel Chinese Graduate Students With Ties to China’s Military Schools
item.description: The move is the latest in the Trump administration’s efforts to impose limits on Chinese students. But university officials say the government is paranoid, and that the United States will lose out.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong and Julian E. Barnes
item.media:description: People’s Liberation Army soldiers marching on Wednesday at the entrance of the Forbidden City in Beijing.

item.title: Senators Seek Answers on Coronavirus Protections at Guantánamo Bay
item.description: In a letter, they asked the Pentagon how the military is safeguarding troops and prisoners from an outbreak of Covid-19 given the base’s limited health care facilities.
item.dc:creator: Carol Rosenberg
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: The medical clinic at Guantanamo Bay’s detention center. Health care on the base is limited for detainees and service members.

item.title: Get Republicans to Vote Against Trump? This Group Will Spend $10 Million to Try
item.description: A new organization, Republican Voters Against Trump, is testing the premise of whether there are really any persuadable voters left.
item.dc:creator: Annie Karni
item.media:credit: Republicans for the Rule of Law
item.media:description: The group Republican Voters Against Trump has created a cache of 100 testimonial videos from voters explaining their decision to break with the party.

item.title: 23 Poets Laureate Receive Fellowships for Projects Around the U.S.
item.description: The program, now in its second year, was expanded from 13 poets in 2019 thanks to a $4.5 million grant from the Mellon Foundation.
item.dc:creator: Concepción de León
item.media:description: Honey Bell-Bey is the poet laureate for Cuyahoga County in Ohio, one of 23 recipients of fellowships from the Academy of American Poets.

item.title: U.S. Jobless Claims Pass 40 Million: Live Business Updates
item.description: The latest on stock market and business news during the coronavirus outbreak.
item.media:description: Lining up for food outside a church in Jackson Heights, Queens, on Tuesday.

item.title: Where Coronavirus Help on Facebook Is ‘Inherently Political’
item.description: Three young organizers in the Detroit area started a group for people to offer face masks, emergency cash or help navigating unemployment. They see it as part of a larger vision.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Medina
item.media:credit: Emily Rose Bennett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Justin Onwenu, an organizer of a Facebook group offering people help amid the health crisis, said, “For my age group, if we don’t walk away from this moment understanding there are things we really need to change, we will have failed.”

item.title: Trump Prepares Social Media Executive Order to Limit Protections
item.description: The move is almost certain to face a court challenge and signals the latest salvo by President Trump to crack down on online platforms.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Haberman and Kate Conger
item.media:description: President Trump and his supporters have long accused social media companies like Twitter of silencing conservative voices.

item.title: G.E., Which Traces Its Roots to Thomas Edison, Sells Its Lighting Business
item.description: The transaction represented a symbolic closing to G.E.’s opening chapters in the second Industrial Revolution.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson
item.media:description: General Electric, long synonymous with the light bulb, sold its lighting business to Savant Systems Inc., a home automation company based in Massachusetts.

item.title: Live Coronavirus News: World Updates
item.description: Another 700,000 infections have been reported in just the last week as the Americas and the Middle East confronted more cases. And in Mexico, the pandemic is straining a hobbled health care system.
item.media:credit: Dado Galdieri for The New York Times
item.media:description: Adaílton Filho kneels to pray at the grave of his grandfather, José Maria Silva, who died of from Covid-19. He was buried in an area exclusively for coronavirus cases at Caju cemetery in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, this month.

item.title: Rep. Sam Johnson of Texas Dies at 89
item.description: Mr. Johnson was a military pilot who spent years as a prisoner of war in Vietnam before serving more than two decades representing a Dallas-area district in Congress.
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: The Giant 'Murder Hornet' Resurfaces in Washington and British Columbia
item.description: The large invasive insect, sometimes known as the “murder hornet,” appears to have resurfaced in both British Columbia and Washington State.
item.dc:creator: Mike Baker
item.media:description: A dead Asian giant hornet was placed on the entomologist Chris Looney’s jacket in Blaine, Wash., in April. With a potent stinger, the hornet can be a public health threat if someone is stung repeatedly.

item.title: UConn Student Wanted in 2 Homicides is Caught in Maryland
item.description: Mr. Manfredonia, 23, had been a fugitive since Friday, when the college senior began a series of violent crimes, the authorities said.
item.dc:creator: Neil Vigdor and Michael Levenson
item.media:credit: Connecticut State Police, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Peter Manfredonia had been wanted in a sequence of violent events that included a home invasion and kidnapping.

item.title: ‘We Loved Each Other’: Fauci Recalls Larry Kramer, Friend and Nemesis
item.description: In public, the activist berated the infectious disease expert for federal inaction on AIDS. But their affection lasted decades and changed the course of the epidemic.
item.dc:creator: Donald G. McNeil Jr.
item.media:description: Larry Kramer in 2015. “It was an extraordinary 33-year relationship,” Dr. Anthony Fauci said of his friendship with the activist.

item.title: U.S. to Penalize Work at Iranian Facilities in Latest Blow to Nuclear Accord
item.description: International workers will no longer be able to keep a watchful eye on the nuclear programs, risking a layer of security that had sought to ensure Iran could not secretly violate a 2015 deal with world powers.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes
item.media:description: The Bushehr nuclear power plant in Iran last year during a ceremony to start work on a second reactor there.

item.title: Minneapolis Police, Long Accused of Racism, Face Wrath of Wounded City
item.description: Protesters returned to the streets on Wednesday, a day after George Floyd’s death. The city’s Police Department has received many excessive force complaints, especially by black residents.
item.dc:creator: Matt Furber, John Eligon and Audra D. S. Burch

item.title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
item.description: More than 100,000 Americans have now died from the virus.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe and Lara Takenaga

item.title: Julián Castro: ‘It’s a Totally Porous Safety Net’
item.description: The former presidential candidate on lessons from the pandemic, his next moves and why Joe Biden needs Latino voters.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Lerer and Jennifer Medina

item.title: As a Federal Coronavirus Expert Frets, the Capital Moves to Reopen
item.description: Like many areas around the country, Washington and its suburbs are embracing positive momentum in data on infections to push ahead.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Steinhauer
item.media:credit: Alyssa Schukar for The New York Times
item.media:description: June Ward and her daughter Autumn Ward near the Lincoln Memorial. Washington’s mayor, Muriel E. Bowser, said parts of the city would begin to reopen on Friday.

item.title: QuarantineChat Brings Back Spontaneity (and Distraction)
item.description: Phone calls with strangers can reintroduce random connections into our locked-down lives, and be a balm for loneliness and grief.
item.dc:creator: Devi Lockwood
item.media:description: Danielle Baskin, who founded QuarantineChat with Max Hawkins. The app randomly connects people around the world. Baskin said she hoped the calls would “kindle unexpected friendships.”

item.title: Rosenstein to Testify on Russia Inquiry to Panel Led by Trump Ally
item.description: The former deputy attorney general was a key part of the investigation. The hearing will also give Trump allies a prominent platform to attack it.
item.dc:creator: Katie Benner
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
item.media:credit: Tom Brenner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rod J. Rosenstein, the former deputy attorney general, appointed Robert S. Mueller III as special counsel to investigate Russia’s 2016 election interference.

item.title: How Do You Lead a State’s Coronavirus Response? Ask Her
item.description: Illinois’s health director, Dr. Ngozi Ezike, offers a glimpse into the round-the-clock, all-consuming effort of containing the coronavirus.
item.dc:creator: Alisha Haridasani Gupta

item.title: House Passes Uighur Human Rights Bill, Prodding Trump to Punish China
item.description: The House overwhelmingly cleared legislation that would punish top Chinese officials for detaining more than one million Muslims in internment camps.
item.dc:creator: Catie Edmondson
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Uighur men at a mosque in China’s Xinjiang region last year.

item.title: Twitter Comes Under Attack From Trump’s Supporters
item.description: After the social media company labeled two of the president’s tweets as inaccurate on Tuesday, his adherents pounced.
item.dc:creator: Kate Conger and Davey Alba
item.media:description: The backlash against Twitter came from a variety of sources: elected officials, conservative websites, pundits and individuals.

item.title: ‘Just Sitting in Limbo.’ For Many Professionals, Careers Are on Hold.
item.description: Even for well-connected high earners, hiring has dried up, advancement has ceased, job searches have paused and new ventures are in jeopardy.
item.dc:creator: David Gelles
item.media:credit: Nicholas Albrecht for The New York Times
item.media:description: “I’m mostly having Zoom calls with strangers,” said Hasti Nazem, who left her job just before the shutdown.

item.title: Tropical Storm Bertha Could Cause Dangerous Flooding in the South
item.description: Bertha was named a tropical storm less than two hours before it made landfall near Charleston, S.C., on Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson

item.title: States Sue to Block Trump From Weakening Fuel Economy Rules
item.description: At stake in the lawsuit is the single biggest effort by the United States to fight the climate crisis.
item.dc:creator: Hiroko Tabuchi
item.media:credit: Max Whittaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: Morning traffic on Highway 580 near Livermore, Calif. The state is leading a coalition in a lawsuit against the Trump administration.

item.title: At Cape Canaveral, Trump’s Search for a Heroic Narrative Is Thwarted
item.description: The president had hoped to watch the first launch of NASA astronauts into orbit from the United States in nearly a decade. Nothing would say the U.S. is back with more verve than a rocket’s red glare.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker and Michael D. Shear
item.media:description: President Trump and the first lady, Melania Trump, arriving on Wednesday in Florida.

item.title: Coronavirus Epidemics Began Later Than Believed, Study Concludes
item.description: In Washington State and Italy, the first confirmed cases were not linked to the outbreaks that followed, the analysis found. The epidemics were seeded later.
item.dc:creator: Carl Zimmer
item.media:description: A library of coronavirus samples for gene sequencing at a University of Washington lab last month.

item.title: Activists and Celebrities Honor Larry Kramer’s Brash Advocacy
item.description: Mr. Kramer, who died on Wednesday, was remembered for his pioneering and often confrontational work during the early days of the AIDS crisis.
item.dc:creator: Johnny Diaz and Sandra E. Garcia
item.media:credit: Joshua Bright for The New York Times
item.media:description: An illustration of Larry Kramer in his Manhattan apartment.

item.title: Ravi Zacharias, Preacher Who Used Reason to Defend Faith, Dies at 74
item.description: The influential evangelist sought to “connect the gospel with the life of the mind.”
item.dc:creator: Steven Kurutz

item.title: Coronavirus Isn’t Keeping Florida Crowds From SpaceX Launch
item.description: Many beachside hotels along the state’s Space Coast were already at capacity before Wednesday’s scheduled launch, a local tourism executive said.
item.dc:creator: Mariel Padilla
item.media:description: Early risers in Titusville, Fla., claimed spots to watch the launch on Wednesday.
